results.title: The Whyalla story
results.creator_credit: Broken Hill Proprietary Company and Solarchrome
results.brief_description: This film shows the location of the town of Whyalla, population, water supply, reason for the town’s establishment, loading ore on to trucks and ships, blast furnaes and their operation, loading of pig iron, shipbuilding and finally the education and recreational facilities of the population. Commentary by John Sherwood.

results.title: The Whole world over
results.creator_credit: Julian Biggs, ONF | NFB, Don Haldane and Leonard Forest
results.brief_description: A trio of stories, set in three of the world’s great cities. Illustrates the theme that people, no matter who they are, or where they live, share the basic human qualities of love, kindness, generosity and compassion. Shows a teenage girl in Amsterdam, a hard-pressed business man in Montreal and a wistful little boy in Mexico City in episodes displaying their response to other people’s needs.

results.title: The Whole world is watching
results.brief_description: An examination of the question of bias in television newscasting. Network executives and reporters discuss such topics as advertising influences on news content, where the responsibility for good news reporting lies, and whether or not television reports news or attempts to make it. Documents what has become a continuing discussion of television newscasters and balanced material.

results.title: The Whole works
results.creator_credit: Leon Clore, Basic Films, British Productivity Council and Margaret Thomson
results.brief_description: Records the reorganization of production in accordance with Work Study principles at a British engineering firm. The firm’s problem was that it made a variety of products in limited numbers and, in addition, worked in cramped buildings. Meetings and discussions over models and diagrams of the present system by which material moved up and down and in and out of the works, and plans of other systems, resulted in the designing of a more efficient flow line running at right angles to the previous one. This meant moving two hundred machines without stopping production. In addition, Departments were each grouped with their own stores and offices, and the production control office streamlined.

results.title: The Whole truth (1976)
results.creator_credit: Films Incorporated, Thomas Walsh and Michael Spewak
results.brief_description: A backstage look at the making of ‘To tell the truth’, one of television’s longest running and most consistently popular game shows, captures the incredible pace of producing not one but five shows in a day.

results.title: The Whole man
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Collings, Dahl Collings, Collings Productions and John Gray
results.brief_description: Training at the Royal South Sydney Hospital Rehabilitation Centre: tells the story of a coal miner, Vic McGee, who loses both feet in an accident. He and others are taught special exercises not only to maintain physical fitness, but also to build morale.

results.title: The Who: who's better, who's best
results.brief_description: The Who! What’s in a name you say? everything, especially when you talk about the world’s greatest rock ‘n’ roll band, a name bestowed upon this group of 4 English musicians in the mid ‘70’s. The Who, formed in 1964 and consisting of Keith Moon on drums, John Entwhistle on bass guitar and vocals, Pete Townshend - lead guitar, vocals and major lyricist for the group and Roger Daltry - main vocals. All of the tracks included on the tape come from the album “Who’s Better, Who’s Best” (made in 1980), although this video does take you on a journey from 1966 through to 1978. Moon died tragically in August of that year. Keith Moon’s distinct style of drumming is evident in all the film clips except for “You Better, You Bet” with Kenny Jones on drums. The song “Pinball Wizard” from the Rock Opera “Tommy” - considered by many as the definitive rock album, is only one of the many hits contained on the tape. As is “Won’t Get Fooled Again”, filmed at the Shepparton Studios in July 1978 and became the group’s signature song. Song on the tape include: “My Generation”; “I can’t explain”; “Substitute”; “The kids are alright”; “I’m a boy”; “Happy Jack”; “Pictures of Lily”; “You better, you bet”; “I can see for miles”; “Magic bus”; “Pinball wizard”; “I’m free”; “See me, feel me”; “Join together”; “Who are you” and “Won’t get fooled again”.

results.title: The Whites' last stand
results.creator_credit: Stephen Clarke, Stewart Lansley, Mick Gold, Nihon Hoso Kyokai, South African Broadcasting Corporation (SABC), VPRO, Discovery Channel, BBC and Brian Lapping Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Death of apartheid”.
Final part of a three-part television series covering the events in South Africa from 1985 to the democratic election in 1994. In 1992 a conference was held between the ruling National Party and the ANC to negotiate towards a free and fair election. Tentative agreement was reached. A further summit was held in April 1993 at the World Trade Centre near Johannesburg and finally it was agreed that the new Government would be formed on a power-sharing basis for five years, ie the National Party and the ANC and that the Cabinet, with its majority, freely able to make decisions without interference or vetoing from the minority National Party. The election date was set for April 1994. This decision angered the right-winged Afrikaners, particularly Eugene Terre’Blanche an extremist and eventual leader of the AWB (Afrikaner Resistance Movement). An alliance of 20 right-winged Afrikaner movements including AWB was formed and became known as the “Volksfront”. Their aim - a separate white state. At the same time, some of the 14 black tribal states (all of which would be abolished after the elections), along with the Zulu Inkatha movement, also fiercely opposed the ANC/National Party alliance and the months preceding the election saw once again violent attacks and demonstrations. It would be this strange alliance between the white Afrikaners and the black right-winged movements that would eventually bring their own downfall and pave the way for a democratic election to take place on 27 April 1994. On 10 May 1994 Nelson Mandela became the inaugural first President of Democratic South Africa with the ANC polling 63% of the vote, National Party 20% and Inkatha 10%. Features interviews, personal commentary and archival and newsreel footage (some parts in b&w). Narrated by Alister Sparks.

results.title: The White walking stick
results.brief_description: To be blind is not to be cut off from everything in life, there are still shapes, smells, and sounds to be understood and enjoyed. The Blind Institute in Auckland undertakes to teach the blind and partially blind to becomes self sufficient and happily employed. Blind persons are shown in various industries. A housewife is shown cooking with the aid of Braille thermometer and cookery book. In the school for blind children every child is given individual tuition and taught to co-ordinate fingertips and brain. It is in music that blind people excel.

results.title: The White ship
results.creator_credit: Rex Tasker, ONF | NFB and Hector Lemieux
results.brief_description: Shows one of the Portuguese schooners that still fish the Grand Banks of Newfoundland. Follows the ship and its crew from the time the townsfolk turn out for the blessing, until the ship returns with the season’s catch, and leaving one crewman in a Newfoundland grave.
